thread.section_title: National News -  New York Daily News
thread.title: Kellyanne Conway implies Michael Flynn could have kept his job
thread.title_full: Kellyanne Conway implies Michael Flynn could have kept his job

author: JASON SILVERSTEIN
title: Kellyanne Conway implies Michael Flynn could have kept his job
text:
Kellyanne Conway implies Michael Flynn would have remained in White House if he didn’t resign, despite misleading officials Kellyanne Conway implies Michael Flynn could have kept his job Kellyanne Conway spoke about Michael Flynn on "Today." (NBC) NEW YORK DAILY NEWS Updated:   8:34 AM 
White House counselor Kellyanne Conway implied Tuesday that Michael Flynn would have remained the national security advisor — and retained President Trump’s trust — if he hadn't decided to resign. 
“The President is very loyal, he’s a very loyal person, but Mike Flynn decided it was best to resign," Conway told “Today” the morning after Flynn’s sudden exit. 
"He knew he’d become a lightning rod and he made that decision." 
Host Matt Lauer asked Conway if that meant Trump would have kept Flynn on board had he not stepped down. Conway did not directly answer, but said Flynn’s role had become “unsustainable” since he misled the administration about his call with America’s Russian ambassador. — TODAY (@TODAYshow) February 14, 2017 
As Lauer pointed out, that logic does not hold up. The Justice Department warned the White House last month that Flynn mischaracterized his December call — in which he discussed lifting sanctions placed by former President Obama — and left himself vulnerable to blackmail by the Russians. 
Conway, appearing exhausted on air, called that warning “one characterization” of the call. She said Flynn continued attending daily briefings and calls up through the day he resigned. 
“As time wore on, obviously the situation became unsustainable,” she said. Michael Flynn resigned Monday night. (YURI GRIPAS/REUTERS) 
Russian lawmakers defend Michael Flynn, blame U.S. for his exit 
He pointed out that Flynn, a retired general with three decades of military experience, should have known that a call with a Russian ambassador would likely have been wiretapped by American intelligence officials and subject to severe scrutiny. 
“The key here, and I want to repeat it, is the misleading of the vice president and others,” Conway said. Tags:
